title: Statistics: Distributions and Summary Measures
description: Data tells a story — but only if you know how to read it. Students learn to ask statistical questions (ones that expect variability), create and read dot plots, histograms, and box plots, calculate measures of center (mean, median) and variability (range, IQR), and compare two distributions using shape, center, and spread with claim-and-evidence reasoning.
goals: Distinguish statistical questions from non-statistical questions by identifying whether variability is expected in the answers
Create and interpret dot plots, histograms, and box plots to represent data distributions
Calculate measures of center (mean, median) and measures of variability (range, IQR) for a data set
Describe the shape of a distribution as symmetric, skewed left, or skewed right
Compare two data sets using shape, center, and spread, supporting conclusions with claim-and-evidence reasoning
instructionalStrategy: Gradual release: concept-intro → I Do → We Do → You Do for each skill
AI uses scaffold array as scope and worked-example bank; flexes within each phase based on student responses
Use real-world, student-friendly contexts (sports stats, class surveys, video game scores) to keep 11-12 year olds engaged
Emphasize precise vocabulary: distribution, variability, center, spread, five-number summary
Build toward claim-and-evidence reasoning in the final skill so students practice constructing short data-supported arguments

scaffold.title: What Makes a Question Statistical?
scaffold.content: Not every question is a statistics question. A statistical question is one where you expect variability in the answers — different people, different trials, or different observations will give you different data. If a question has one exact answer, it is not statistical. Learning to tell the difference is the first step in thinking like a data scientist.
keyPoints: A statistical question expects variability — different data points will give different answers.
A non-statistical question has a single, fixed answer (e.g., 'How many days are in January?' is always 31).
Example of a statistical question: 'How many hours per night do 6th graders sleep?' — answers vary from student to student.
Statistical questions lead to data collection — you need to gather multiple values to answer them.
The word 'typical' is a clue: 'What is a typical quiz score in our class?' is statistical because scores vary.

scaffold.title: Statistical vs. Non-Statistical Questions — Worked Examples

examples.problem:
Classify each question as statistical or non-statistical:
(a) 'How tall is the Statue of Liberty?'
(b) 'How tall are the students in Mr. Ruiz's 6th-grade class?'
examples.solution:
(a) Non-statistical — there is one definite answer (about 305 feet). No variability.
(b) Statistical — students have different heights, so we expect variability in the data. You would need to measure many students and the answers would differ.

examples.problem:
'What was the high temperature in Phoenix on January 1, 2025?' — Is this statistical?
What about: 'What are the high temperatures in Phoenix during January?'
examples.solution:
The first question has one exact answer for that specific date — non-statistical.
The second question expects variability because the high temperature changes from day to day during January. That makes it statistical; you would collect 31 different data points and the values would vary.

problems.question: Marcus wants to know about his classmates' video game habits. He writes: 'How many hours per week do 6th graders spend playing video games?' Is this a statistical question? Explain why or why not.
hints: Does this question have one fixed answer, or would you expect different answers from different students?
If you surveyed 30 classmates, would they all give the same number?
problems.answer: Yes, this is a statistical question. Different students play different amounts, so there is variability in the data. Surveying the class would produce a range of different values.

problems.question:
Which of these is a statistical question?
(A) 'How many pages are in our math textbook?'
(B) 'How many pages did students in our class read last month?'
(C) 'What is the school's street address?'
(D) 'Who is the principal of our school?'
hints: A statistical question anticipates variability — different data points give different answers.
Which question would produce different answers from different people?
problems.answer: (B) 'How many pages did students in our class read last month?' Each student read a different number of pages, so we expect variability. The other three questions each have one fixed answer.

problems.question: Rewrite this non-statistical question into a statistical one: 'How many points did LeBron James score on February 3?'
hints: The original has one exact answer. How could you change it so the answer involves variability?
Think about asking across multiple games, multiple players, or a time period.
problems.answer: A good revision: 'How many points per game did LeBron James score this season?' or 'How many points do NBA players typically score per game?' Both versions expect variability because the values change across games or across players.

problems.question:
Sort these questions into Statistical or Non-Statistical:
(1) 'What is the average rainfall in Seattle during April?'
(2) 'How many inches of rain fell in Seattle on April 10?'
(3) 'How many pets do students in our school have?'
(4) 'What is the school lunch menu today?'
problems.answer: Statistical: (1) and (3) — both expect variability across multiple days or students. Non-Statistical: (2) and (4) — both have a single, fixed answer.

problems.question: A survey asks 25 sixth graders: 'How many siblings do you have?' Is this a statistical question? If 25 students answered, would you expect variability in the data? Explain.
problems.answer: Yes, this is a statistical question. Different students have different numbers of siblings (some have 0, some have 1, 2, or more), so there is variability. Surveying 25 students would produce a data set with a range of different values.

scaffold.title: Data Displays: Dot Plots, Histograms, and Box Plots
scaffold.content: Data displays help us see patterns and shapes in data at a glance. In 6th grade, you will work with three main types of displays: dot plots (great for small data sets), histograms (great for showing how data is distributed across intervals), and box plots (great for summarizing and comparing data sets using the five-number summary).
keyPoints: Dot plot: place one dot above a number line for each data value. Stacked dots show how often a value occurs.
Histogram: data is grouped into equal-width intervals called bins. Each bar's height shows the frequency (count) for that bin. There are no gaps between bars.
Box plot: built from the five-number summary — minimum, Q1 (lower quartile), median, Q3 (upper quartile), and maximum.
To find Q1 and Q3: order the data, find the median of the lower half (Q1) and the median of the upper half (Q3).
The box in a box plot spans from Q1 to Q3 and contains the middle 50% of the data. The line inside the box marks the median.
Choosing the right display: use a dot plot for fewer than about 25 values, a histogram for larger data sets showing shape, and box plots when comparing two or more groups side by side.

examples.problem:
A dot plot shows the number of goals scored by players on a soccer team this season:
Goals:  0(2 dots)  1(4 dots)  2(3 dots)  3(2 dots)  4(1 dot)  5(1 dot)
How many players are on the team? What is the most common number of goals?
examples.solution:
Count all the dots: 2 + 4 + 3 + 2 + 1 + 1 = 13 players total.
The most common number of goals is 1, with 4 dots stacked above it. The mode is 1 goal.

examples.problem:
A histogram shows test scores for a class:
50-59: 2 students | 60-69: 5 students | 70-79: 10 students | 80-89: 8 students | 90-99: 5 students
How many students scored 70 or above?
examples.solution:
Add the frequencies for the bins 70-79, 80-89, and 90-99:
10 + 8 + 5 = 23 students scored 70 or above.
Total class size: 2 + 5 + 10 + 8 + 5 = 30 students.

examples.problem:
Find the five-number summary for this data set:
12, 15, 18, 20, 22, 25, 28, 30, 35
examples.solution:
Min = 12, Max = 35.
With 9 values, the median is the 5th value: 22.
Lower half (values below the median): 12, 15, 18, 20 → Q1 = (15 + 18) / 2 = 16.5
Upper half (values above the median): 25, 28, 30, 35 → Q3 = (28 + 30) / 2 = 29
Five-number summary: Min = 12, Q1 = 16.5, Median = 22, Q3 = 29, Max = 35.

problems.question:
The following data shows the number of books 10 students read over the summer:
2, 5, 3, 7, 4, 3, 6, 2, 5, 3
If you made a dot plot, how many dots would be stacked above the number 3? What value has the most dots?
hints: Count how many times the number 3 appears in the data set.
List each value and its frequency: 2 appears ___, 3 appears ___, 4 appears ___, 5 appears ___, 6 appears ___, 7 appears ___.
problems.answer: The number 3 appears 3 times, so 3 dots would be stacked above it. Frequencies: 2 → 2, 3 → 3, 4 → 1, 5 → 2, 6 → 1, 7 → 1. The value 3 has the most dots (frequency of 3), making it the mode.

problems.question:
A histogram of daily high temperatures (°F) during June shows:
60-69: 3 days | 70-79: 8 days | 80-89: 12 days | 90-99: 7 days
(a) How many days of data are represented?
(b) What percentage of days had temperatures in the 80s?
hints: Add all the frequencies together to find the total number of days.
Percentage = (frequency for 80-89) ÷ total × 100.
problems.answer: (a) 3 + 8 + 12 + 7 = 30 days. (b) 12 out of 30 days = 12 ÷ 30 = 0.40 = 40% of days had temperatures in the 80-89°F range.

problems.question:
Find the five-number summary for this data set of quiz scores:
65, 70, 72, 78, 80, 85, 88, 90, 92, 95
Then calculate the IQR.
hints: The data is already in order. With 10 values, the median is the average of the 5th and 6th values.
The lower half is the first 5 values; Q1 is the median of those (the 3rd). The upper half is the last 5 values; Q3 is the median of those.
IQR = Q3 − Q1.
problems.answer: Min = 65. Lower half: 65, 70, 72, 78, 80 → Q1 = 72 (the 3rd value). Median = (80 + 85) / 2 = 82.5. Upper half: 85, 88, 90, 92, 95 → Q3 = 90 (the 3rd value). Max = 95. IQR = 90 − 72 = 18.

problems.question:
A dot plot shows the number of free throws made (out of 10) by players during basketball practice:
3, 4, 4, 5, 5, 5, 6, 6, 7, 8
How many players made 5 or more free throws?
problems.answer: Count values that are 5 or greater: 5, 5, 5, 6, 6, 7, 8. That is 7 players who made 5 or more free throws.

problems.question:
A histogram of students' daily screen time (hours) shows:
0-1 hrs: 4 students | 1-2 hrs: 9 students | 2-3 hrs: 11 students | 3-4 hrs: 6 students | 4-5 hrs: 2 students
What fraction of students have 2 or more hours of screen time per day?
problems.answer: Students with 2+ hours: 11 + 6 + 2 = 19. Total students: 4 + 9 + 11 + 6 + 2 = 32. Fraction = 19/32.

problems.question:
A box plot of video game high scores shows: min = 120, Q1 = 200, median = 310, Q3 = 450, max = 580.
(a) What is the range?
(b) What is the IQR?
(c) What percentage of scores fall between 200 and 450?
problems.answer: (a) Range = 580 − 120 = 460. (b) IQR = 450 − 200 = 250. (c) 50% of the scores fall between Q1 (200) and Q3 (450), since the box contains the middle 50% of the data.

scaffold.title: Measures of Center and Variability
scaffold.content: Once you have collected data, you need numbers to summarize it. Measures of center tell you where the 'middle' or 'typical' value is. Measures of variability tell you how spread out the data is. Together, center and variability give a complete numerical picture of a data set.
keyPoints: Mean (average): add all data values and divide by the count. Think of it as the 'fair share' — if you redistributed all the data evenly, each value would equal the mean.
Median: arrange values from least to greatest and find the middle value. With an even number of values, average the two middle values.
The mean is sensitive to outliers (extreme values pull it up or down), while the median is resistant — it stays near the center even with outliers.
Range: maximum minus minimum. It measures total spread but can be affected by a single outlier.
Interquartile Range (IQR): Q3 minus Q1. It measures the spread of the middle 50% of the data and ignores extremes.
When data is symmetric, mean and median are close together. When data is skewed or has outliers, the median and IQR give a more accurate picture.

scaffold.title: Calculating Center and Variability — Worked Examples

examples.problem: Find the mean and median of these test scores: 78, 82, 85, 90, 95.
examples.solution:
Mean = (78 + 82 + 85 + 90 + 95) ÷ 5 = 430 ÷ 5 = 86.
Median = the middle value (3rd of 5) = 85.
The mean (86) and median (85) are close, which tells us the data is roughly symmetric.

examples.problem: A basketball team scored these points in 7 games: 45, 52, 58, 60, 63, 67, 72. Find the range and IQR.
examples.solution:
Range = 72 − 45 = 27 points.
Median = 60 (the 4th of 7 values).
Lower half: 45, 52, 58 → Q1 = 52.
Upper half: 63, 67, 72 → Q3 = 67.
IQR = 67 − 52 = 15.
The middle 50% of scores are within a 15-point range.

examples.problem: Students recorded their daily screen time in minutes: 30, 45, 50, 55, 60, 60, 65, 200. The value 200 is an outlier. Should you use mean or median to describe the typical screen time?
examples.solution:
Mean = (30 + 45 + 50 + 55 + 60 + 60 + 65 + 200) ÷ 8 = 565 ÷ 8 = 70.6 minutes.
Median = (55 + 60) ÷ 2 = 57.5 minutes.
The mean (70.6) is pulled up by the outlier of 200. The median (57.5) better represents the typical student's screen time. Use the median when there are outliers.

problems.question: A group of friends tracked how many text messages they sent in one day: 12, 15, 22, 18, 33. Calculate the mean number of texts.
hints: Add all five values together: 12 + 15 + 22 + 18 + 33.
Divide the sum by 5 (the number of data values).

problems.question: Find the median of these soccer jersey numbers picked for a drill: 4, 11, 7, 2, 15, 9, 20, 1. (Careful — the data must be ordered first!)
hints: First, arrange the values from least to greatest: 1, 2, 4, 7, 9, 11, 15, 20.
With 8 values (even count), the median is the average of the 4th and 5th values.
problems.answer: Ordered: 1, 2, 4, 7, 9, 11, 15, 20. The 4th value is 7 and the 5th value is 9. Median = (7 + 9) ÷ 2 = 8.

problems.question:
The ages of players on a youth volleyball team are: 10, 11, 11, 12, 12, 12, 13, 13, 14. Find:
(a) the range
(b) Q1, Q3, and the IQR
hints: Range = maximum − minimum.
With 9 values, the median is the 5th value (12). The lower half is the first 4 values: 10, 11, 11, 12. Q1 is the median of those.
The upper half is the last 4 values: 12, 13, 13, 14. Q3 is the median of those. IQR = Q3 − Q1.

scaffold.title: Center and Variability — On Your Own

problems.question: Students in a science class measured the length (in cm) of 6 earthworms: 8, 12, 15, 9, 11, 17. Find the mean length.

A student's quiz scores this semester are: 70, 85, 88, 90, 92, 95, 100. The teacher accidentally entered one score as 10 instead of 100.
(a) Find the median of the correct data set.
(b) Would the mean or the median change more because of this error? Explain.
problems.answer: (a) Correct data ordered: 70, 85, 88, 90, 92, 95, 100. Median = 90 (the 4th of 7 values). (b) The mean changes much more. With the error (10 instead of 100), the sum drops by 90, pulling the mean way down. The median stays at 88 (reordered: 10, 70, 85, 88, 92, 95, 100 — still the 4th value). This shows the median is resistant to outliers while the mean is not.

problems.question:
Two friends compared their weekly step counts (in thousands):
Friend A: 5, 7, 8, 8, 9, 11
Friend B: 3, 5, 8, 10, 12, 14
Find the IQR for each friend. Who has more variability in their step counts?
problems.answer: Friend A: Lower half: 5, 7, 8 → Q1 = 7. Upper half: 8, 9, 11 → Q3 = 9. IQR = 9 − 7 = 2. Friend B: Lower half: 3, 5, 8 → Q1 = 5. Upper half: 10, 12, 14 → Q3 = 12. IQR = 12 − 5 = 7. Friend B has more variability (IQR of 7 vs. 2), meaning their step count changes much more from week to week.

scaffold.title: Comparing Distributions
scaffold.content: Once you can describe one distribution, the real power of statistics comes from comparing two distributions. Sports teams, classes, cities — any time you have two data sets, you can compare their shapes, centers, and spreads to make a claim about which group performed better, was more consistent, or differed in some important way.
keyPoints: Shape: describe each distribution as symmetric (roughly a mirror image), skewed right (tail stretches right, most data clusters left), or skewed left (tail stretches left, most data clusters right).
Center: compare the mean or median of each group. A higher center means the typical value is larger.
Spread: compare the range or IQR of each group. A larger spread means more variability — data is less consistent.
When comparing, always state a claim and back it up with specific numbers as evidence. Example: 'Team A is typically faster (median of 12 seconds vs. 15 seconds).'
Side-by-side box plots are especially useful for comparisons — you can visually compare medians, IQRs, and overall ranges at a glance.

examples.problem:
Two classes took the same math test. Here are their box plot summaries:
Class A: min = 55, Q1 = 65, median = 75, Q3 = 85, max = 95
Class B: min = 60, Q1 = 72, median = 80, Q3 = 88, max = 98
Compare the two distributions using center and spread.
examples.solution:
Center: Class B has a higher median (80 vs. 75), so the typical score in Class B is 5 points higher.
Spread: Class A's IQR = 85 − 65 = 20. Class B's IQR = 88 − 72 = 16. Class A's scores are more spread out.
Class A's range = 95 − 55 = 40. Class B's range = 98 − 60 = 38. Overall spreads are similar.
Claim: Class B performed better on this test — its median is 5 points higher and its scores are more tightly grouped (IQR of 16 vs. 20).

examples.problem:
A survey asked students how many hours they slept last night.
6th graders: 6, 7, 7, 8, 8, 8, 8, 9, 9, 10
7th graders: 5, 5, 6, 6, 7, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11
Describe the shape of each distribution and compare the centers.
examples.solution:
6th graders: Mean = (6+7+7+8+8+8+8+9+9+10) ÷ 10 = 80 ÷ 10 = 8. Median = (8+8) ÷ 2 = 8. Data clusters around 8 — roughly symmetric.
7th graders: Mean = (5+5+6+6+7+7+8+9+10+11) ÷ 10 = 74 ÷ 10 = 7.4. Median = (7+7) ÷ 2 = 7. Data is more spread out — roughly symmetric but wider.
Claim: 6th graders typically got more sleep. Evidence: the 6th-grade median is 8 hours vs. 7 hours for 7th graders. The 7th graders' data also has a wider range (6 vs. 4), showing more variability in sleep habits.

problems.question:
Two basketball players' points per game are summarized in box plots:
Player A: min = 8, Q1 = 12, median = 18, Q3 = 22, max = 30
Player B: min = 10, Q1 = 15, median = 20, Q3 = 24, max = 28
(a) Who has the higher typical score? Use the median as evidence.
(b) Who is more consistent? Use the IQR as evidence.
hints: Compare the medians: Player A's median = 18, Player B's median = 20.
Find each IQR: IQR = Q3 − Q1. A smaller IQR means more consistency.
problems.answer: (a) Player B has the higher typical score — median of 20 vs. 18. (b) Player A: IQR = 22 − 12 = 10. Player B: IQR = 24 − 15 = 9. Player B is slightly more consistent (smaller IQR of 9 vs. 10). Claim: Player B is the stronger scorer — higher median and more consistent performance.

problems.question:
Two 6th-grade classes did a survey on daily screen time (minutes):
Class X: 20, 30, 30, 40, 45, 50, 50, 55, 60, 120
Class Y: 35, 40, 40, 45, 45, 50, 50, 55, 55, 60
Which class has a more symmetric distribution? Which class has an outlier that affects the mean? Support your answer with calculations.
hints: Calculate the mean and median for each class.
Look for values that are far from the rest of the data — those are outliers.
In a symmetric distribution, the mean and median are close together.
problems.answer: Class X: Mean = 500 ÷ 10 = 50. Median = (45 + 50) ÷ 2 = 47.5. The value 120 is an outlier that pulls the mean above the median. Class Y: Mean = 475 ÷ 10 = 47.5. Median = (45 + 50) ÷ 2 = 47.5. Mean equals median — the distribution is symmetric. Class Y is more symmetric. Class X has an outlier (120 minutes) that raises the mean by 2.5 above the median.

problems.question:
Two soccer teams recorded the number of goals scored per game over 8 games.
Team Lightning: 1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 3, 4, 6
Team Thunder: 0, 1, 1, 2, 4, 5, 5, 6
Find the median and IQR for each team. Write a claim comparing the two teams, supported by evidence.
problems.answer: Team Lightning: Median = (3 + 3) ÷ 2 = 3. Q1 = (2 + 2) ÷ 2 = 2. Q3 = (3 + 4) ÷ 2 = 3.5. IQR = 1.5. Team Thunder: Median = (2 + 4) ÷ 2 = 3. Q1 = (1 + 1) ÷ 2 = 1. Q3 = (5 + 5) ÷ 2 = 5. IQR = 4. Claim: Both teams have the same typical number of goals (median = 3), but Team Lightning is much more consistent (IQR of 1.5 vs. 4). Team Thunder's scoring is more unpredictable.

problems.question:
The box plots for two students' weekly quiz scores show:
Student A: min = 60, Q1 = 70, median = 82, Q3 = 90, max = 100
Student B: min = 75, Q1 = 78, median = 80, Q3 = 84, max = 88
Which student has the higher typical score? Which student is more consistent? Write your answer in claim-and-evidence format.
problems.answer: Claim: Student A has a slightly higher typical score (median 82 vs. 80), but Student B is far more consistent. Evidence: Student A's IQR = 90 − 70 = 20 and range = 100 − 60 = 40. Student B's IQR = 84 − 78 = 6 and range = 88 − 75 = 13. Student B's scores are much more tightly grouped, meaning you can predict Student B's performance more reliably.

problems.question:
A teacher collected data on the number of push-ups completed by two gym classes:
Class A: 10, 12, 15, 15, 18, 20, 22, 25, 28, 35
Class B: 12, 16, 18, 19, 20, 22, 23, 24, 26, 30
Describe the shape of each distribution (symmetric or skewed). Then compare the centers and spreads using at least two measures.
problems.answer: Class A: Mean = 200 ÷ 10 = 20. Median = (18 + 20) ÷ 2 = 19. The mean is slightly above the median, and the value 35 pulls the tail to the right — slight right skew. Q1 = 15, Q3 = 25, IQR = 10, Range = 25. Class B: Mean = 210 ÷ 10 = 21. Median = (20 + 22) ÷ 2 = 21. Mean equals median — roughly symmetric. Q1 = 18, Q3 = 24, IQR = 6, Range = 18. Comparison: Class B has a slightly higher center (median 21 vs. 19) and is more consistent (IQR 6 vs. 10). Class A is more spread out with a slight right skew caused by the high value of 35.

answerKeys.stat-3: How many points per game did LeBron James score this season?
answerKeys.stat-5: Yes — variability expected since students have different numbers of siblings

answerKeys.stat-9: 7 players made 5 or more free throws
answerKeys.stat-16: (a) Median=90. (b) Mean changes more — median is resistant to outliers
answerKeys.stat-17: Friend A IQR=2, Friend B IQR=7. Friend B has more variability
answerKeys.stat-18: (a) Player B (median 20 vs 18). (b) Player B (IQR 9 vs 10)
answerKeys.stat-19: Class Y is symmetric (mean=median=47.5). Class X has outlier 120 affecting the mean
answerKeys.stat-20: Both medians=3. Lightning IQR=1.5, Thunder IQR=4. Lightning is more consistent
